labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Add preference for CIS Container benchmarks
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body: Is there a reference that can be added for the CIS container security benchmarks? (e.g. https://www.cisecurity.org/benchmark/docker?utm_source=chatgpt.com, https://www.cisecurity.org/benchmark/kubernetes?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

comments.author: KME
comments.body: Yes, thanks. We need to add in references!

issues.title: Claims for Container Security Benchmarks
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body: Will this specification define claim values based on container security benchmarks, or is the expectation that those values are defined in the MPS registry?

comments.author: KME
comments.body: The expectation is that those would be in the registry. The reason being is that if you look at what was needed for the TCG Reference Integrity Metrics, each vendor used that single policy and their defined "Golden values" varied. The reason is that firmware was different for each vendor based on their implementation. They may have varied underlying hardware and they may update versions over time. The types of information checked for each would be the same with variances in the configuration settings and measurements.

issues.title: Multiple Benchmarks
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body: Is the expectation that multiple benchmarks will be included in a single MPS, or will there be multiple MPS claims, each with their benchmark (e.g. an array of MPS claims).

comments.author: KME
comments.body: The CIS Benchmarks and DISA STIGS would be quite large to combine. The current intention is to have an MPS represent a single Benchmark and potentially portions of a Benchmark if it makes more sense for some to be broken up into sections to test and complete comparison verifications.

issues.title: Some thoughts about Intro - v1
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
### General thoughts
In general, the problem statement is not yet clear to me. I think a figure in Sec. 1 and defining some terms in Sec. 2 would help. 

In the scope of this document, I would like to understand:

- What is the need/motivation for attestation?
- Who is attesting to whom? 
- Is it local attestation or remote attestation? 
- Compliance is mentioned multiple times in the draft, and I believe there is no "global" compliance; compliance is with reference to a specific regulation. It remains unclear to me which regulation is intended. 
- I am specifically concerned about protocols. Where in this whole assessment process do the protocols get checked? 

### Specific questions
Note: Emphasis in the quoted text is my own 

> By using **policy** and **measurement sets** that may be offered at various assurance levels, **local assessment of evidence** can be performed to continuously assess **compliance**.

- Which policy is this related to: policy for Evidence or Attestation Results? 
- measurement sets: are these Claims or Reference Values? If the former, does it include runtime measurements or just loadtime measurements?
- local assessment of evidence: is the draft about local attestation or remote attestation?
- compliance: compliance with what?

> this kind of **compliance**

compliance with what?

> The **local** system or server host performs the assessment of posture and remediation.

Seems local attestation to me, I am not sure why remote attestation is mentioned in the draft. 

> This document describes a method to use existing remote attestation formats and **protocols**.

This was very interesting for me. But unfortunately, there is no other mention of protocols in the rest of the document.

comments.author: KME
comments.body:
Usama,

Thank you for your thoughtful questions!

you are correct that there are 2 levels of attestation, local to assess policy and then an attestation that is remote to convey a set of results against a defined policy or configuration level. Today, this activity happens, but it does not scale and requires lots of resources. This is the same problem the Huawei proposal is trying to solve, but theirs is with a different architectural pattern. This pattern also considers scale, but factors in transparency required by auditors.

This is setting a general capability with a registry to allow for any defined policy or regulation to be attested using evidence and verification of evidence. Then for the remote attestation, the evidence is assessed to see if all of the conditions are met to fulfill the compliance requirements, verifying sets of local attestations, then attesting to the result. Conveying the smaller result in a way that can be understood due to the registry and defined expectations allows for a small message to be sent. It is not efficient to perform full assessments to a large policy on the wire for a data center with thousands of systems. Huawei approaches this by sending one result for many systems. This posture assessment draft instead sends a small message that links back to the local attestation evidence providing a transparent trail of evidence required for audits to meet both requirements.

Which protocols? Are you asking because of TLS Attestation?

For your question on measurements, yes, we will want to test both at load time and at runtime.

I hope this clarifies further and I'm happy to get on a call if helpful.

comments.author: aj-stein
comments.body: Re @muhammad-usama-sardar's framing questions and specific questions, perhaps we can make some incremental edits and send them to him and the list for review and consideration to ensure we better answer those questions, @KME? We can work on that together if you'd like.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
> Which protocols? Are you asking because of TLS Attestation?

I was referring to the last paragraph of Introduction: 
> This document describes a method to use existing remote attestation
   formats and protocols.


As a general feedback, the draft is currently really hard to read for me. The abstract claims "architectural pattern" but there is no diagram on architecture in the draft. The word "Attester" is never used in the draft. It would be helpful to map the terminology to RATS terminology and add a figure showing the architectural changes compared to 9334. Perhaps the introduction can give a very simple example as motivation of this work.

comments.author: aj-stein
comments.body:
Hi @KME I saw a comment on one of the commits (at https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-posture-assessment/commit/675b3ba8301f2f5bc42697fbb10c77a6af4874ed#commitcomment-160973937). Since @dwelski is not an explicit member of the repository and, as far as GitHub is concerned, an "outside contributor" so to speak, either you or I had to approve taking the draft changes and allowing the GitHub Actions workflow to run. I just did that now.

If you do not want that on a case-by-case basis for Derek, you will want to go the URL below and add `dwelski` with at least write, or maybe maintain, permissions.

https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-posture-assessment/setting/access

Let me know if that is what you were describing or I misunderstood.

comments.body:

I believe that was just an addition or the word "test" into the text. It'll
have to get removed :-)

Let's sync when you have a chance! Best of luck as you transition out of
GSA!

Take care,
Kathleen

comments.author: aj-stein
comments.body:
> Thanks, A.J. I believe that was just an addition or the word "test" into the text. It'll have to get removed :-) Let's sync when you have a chance! Best of luck as you transition out of GSA! Take care, Kathleen

Yes, I encouraged him to experiment to understand how as a series of commits one change at a time get collected and reviewed collectively. We know that is a dummy commit, and we will be sure to get it removed before finalizing the table updates. He is still drafting this pull request and he labelled it thusly. He will likely remove it and let us know when it is ready. I am standing by to help him with it.

Feel free to ask for any help, @dwelski, I get updates commit by commit.

comments.author: aj-stein
comments.body: Given the substantive work you did is in #10 and #11 and this is more of a practice PR, I am going to close this one out for now. Feel free to re-open if I misunderstood.

pulls.title: Update draft-ietf-rats-posture-assessment.md
pulls.author: dwelski
pulls.body: Added "Appendix A – Extended Claims Table: Table A.1" which shows chained attestation and measurement exposure across various hardware  implementations.

reviews.author: aj-stein
reviews.body: Looks good to me. I support merging the changes in this PR.

reviews.author: aj-stein
reviews.body: Wops, I take it back, one minor correction is necessary.

comments.body:
Sorry, I didn't realize this requirement for automated I-D builds, but you have to remove the keyword `Table` explicitly.

```suggestion
### A.1 – Chained Attestation and Measurement Exposure Across Hardware Roots of Trust
```

reviews.author: aj-stein
reviews.body: I fixed the merge conflict, and still happy to accept these changes.

pulls.title: Update draft-ietf-rats-posture-assessment.md
pulls.author: dwelski
pulls.body: Add A2. Extended Claims Table with DICE, Apple Secure Enclave, OpenTitan, and Amazon Nitro

comments.body:
Similar to feedback in https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-posture-assessment/pull/10#discussion_r2188465681, you cannot explicitly use the word `Table` in a heading. Otherwise, it is solid.

```suggestion
### A.2 – Extended Claims Table with DICE, Apple Secure Enclave, OpenTitan, and Amazon Nitro
```
